# Metric Construction


## Definition & Interpretation


$$Days\: of\:Operating \:and\:Investments = \frac{Unrestricted \: Net\:Assets\:+\: Investments\:-\:(Land,\: Building\: and\: Equipment\: + Mortgages\:and\:Notes\:Payable) }{((Total \: Expenses\:-\: Depreciation)/365)}$$


The days of operating cash and investment measures how long an organization would be able to continue operating its programs and investing at its current rate based on its average per-day expenses (excluding depreciation). Note: This ratio is the same as month of cash on hand but it is in days and excludes land and mortgages from the operating cash and investment numerator. The reason that land and mortgage expenses are deducated from the numerator is because those are non-liquid or necessary expenses and shouldn't truly be considered free cash for operating and investment. 

The higher the number of days from this metric, the more protected the system will be against revenue shocks, but the target value is subjective. Generally, a system should aim to maintain several monthsâ€™ worth of cash on hand and at the very least exceed the length of the billing period (usually 30 or 60 days).



## Variables 

Note: This data is available only for organizations that filed 990s using e-file submissions. The data is sourced from AWS. 

* **Numerator:** Unrestricted Net Assets + Investments - (Land, Buildings, and Equipment + Mortgages and Notes Payable)
  <br>
  
  *	On 990: (PART 10, LINE 27 EOY), (PART 10, LINE 8 EOY), (PART-10, LINE 10(C)EOY), (PART-10, LINE 23 EOY)
    - AWS Tax File Data: F9_10_NAFB_UNRESTRICT_EOY, F9_10_ASSET_INV_SALE_EOY, F9_10_ASSET_LAND_BLDG_NET_EOY, F9_10_LIAB_MTG_NOTE_EOY
    <br>
  
  *	On EZ: Not Available
    - AWS Tax File Data: Not Available
  <br>
* **Denominator:** Daily Average Expenses or Total Expenses - Depreciation divided by 365
  *	On 990: PART 9, Line 25(A), PART 9, Line 22(A)
    -AWS Tax File Data: F9_09_EXP_TOT_TOT, F9_09_EXP_DEPREC_TOT
    
  *	On EZ: Not Available
    - AWS Tax File Data: Not Available
  <br>




```{r, eval=T}


# TEMPORARY VARIABLES 
numerator  <- core$F9_10_NAFB_UNRESTRICT_EOY + core$F9_10_ASSET_INV_SALE_EOY-(core$F9_10_ASSET_LAND_BLDG_NET_EOY+core$F9_10_LIAB_MTG_NOTE_EOY)
denom <- ((core$F9_09_EXP_TOT_TOT- core$F9_09_EXP_DEPREC_TOT)/365)

# can't divide by zero
denom[ denom == 0 ] <- NA

# SAVE RESULTS 
core$days_op_inv <-  numerator / denom
                     
# summary( core$days_op_inv )
```


## Standardize Scales

Check high and low values to see what makes sense. 

```{r, fig.height=4}
x.05 <- quantile( core$days_op_inv, 0.05, na.rm=T )
x.95 <- quantile( core$days_op_inv, 0.95, na.rm=T )

ggplot( core, aes(x = days_op_inv ) ) +  
  geom_density( alpha = 0.5) + 
  xlim( x.05, x.95 ) 
```




```{r}
core2 <- core

# proportion of values that are negative
#mean( core2$days_op_inv < 0, na.rm=T ) 
#core2$days_op_inv[ core2$days_op_inv < 0 ] <- 0

# proption of values above 200% 
#mean( core2$days_op_inv > 50, na.rm=T ) 
#core2$days_op_inv[ core2$days_op_inv > 50 ] <- 50



x.05 <- quantile( core$days_op_inv, 0.05, na.rm=T )
x.95 <- quantile( core$days_op_inv, 0.95, na.rm=T )

core2 <- core

# proportion of values that are negative
# mean( core2$der < 0, na.rm=T ) 

# proption of values above 1% 
# mean( core2$der > 5, na.rm=T ) 

# WINSORIZATION AT 5th and 95th PERCENTILES

core2$days_op_inv[ core2$days_op_inv < x.05 ] <- x.05
core2$days_op_inv[ core2$days_op_inv > x.95 ] <- x.95
```



## Metric Scope


Tax data is available for full 990 filers only, and of those, only those organizations that e-file their forms. 

The data have been capped to those with values between 5% and 95% of the normal distribution to cut off outliers and exempt organizations with zero profitability (though negative values are allowed still). 



# Descriptive Statistics


Note: All monetary variables have been converted to thousands of dollars. 

```{r, results="asis"}

core2 %>%
  mutate( #days_op_inv = days_op_inv * 100,
    totrevenue = totrevenue / 1000,
    totfuncexpns = totfuncexpns / 1000, 
    lndbldgsequipend = lndbldgsequipend / 1000,
    totassetsend = totassetsend / 1000,
    totliabend = totliabend / 1000,
    totnetassetend = totnetassetend / 1000 ) %>% 
  select( STATE,  NTEE1, NTMAJ12, 
          days_op_inv, 
          AGE, 
          totrevenue, totfuncexpns, 
          lndbldgsequipend, totassetsend, 
          totnetassetend, totliabend ) %>%

  stargazer( type = s.type, 
             digits=2, 
             summary.stat = c("min","p25","median",
                              "mean","p75","max", "sd"),
             covariate.labels = c("Days of Operating Cash and Investments", "Age", 
                                  "Revenue ($1k)", "Expenses($1k)", 
                                  "Buildings ($1k)", "Total Assets ($1k)",
                                  "Net Assets ($1k)", "Liabiliies ($1k)"))
```



What proportion of orgs have days of operating cash and investments equal to zero?


```{r}
prop.zero <- mean( core2$days_op_inv == 0, na.rm=T )
```


In the sample, `r 100*round(prop.zero,2)` percent of the organizations have days of operating cash and investments equal to zero, meaning they have no cash with which to cover even one day of their expenses. These organizations are dropped from subsequent graphs to keep the visualizations clean. The interpretation of the graphics should be the distributions of days of operating cash and investment for organizations that have positive or negative values.  




```{r}
###
### ADD QUANTILES
###
###   function create_quantiles() defined in r-functions.R

core2$exp.q   <- create_quantiles( var=core2$totfuncexpns,   n.groups=5 )
core2$rev.q   <- create_quantiles( var=core2$totrevenue,     n.groups=5 )
core2$asset.q <- create_quantiles( var=core2$totnetassetend, n.groups=5 )
core2$age.q   <- create_quantiles( var=core2$AGE,            n.groups=5 )
core2$land.q <- create_quantiles(var=core2$lndbldgsequipend,            n.groups=5 )

```
